questions.question: The orator and philosopher ………………….. dead.
questions.description: Here the article is used only once and hence both nouns refer to the same person. Therefore, we need a singular verb here.

questions.question: The artist and the poet …………………….. arrived.
questions.description: Here the article the is used before both the nouns and hence they refer to different people. Therefore, we use a plural verb here.

questions.question: The long and the short of the matter ……………………….. that we cannot continue like this.
questions.description: When two subjects together express one idea, the verb is usually singular in number.

questions.question: Every man and woman …………………………. a vote.
questions.description: When singular subjects are preceded by each or every, the verb is usually singular.

questions.question: Neither Peter nor Harry ………………………… passed the exam.
questions.description: Two or more singular subjects connected by neither … nor take a singular verb.

questions.question: No nook or corner …………………………. left unexplored.
questions.description: Two or more singular subjects connected by or takes a singular verb.

questions.question: Either John or Sam ……………………….. to quit.
questions.description: Two or more singular subjects connected by either…or… take a singular verb.

questions.question: Either you or I ………………………. mistaken.
questions.description: When the subjects joined by or or nor are of different persons, the verb agrees in person with the subject nearest to it.

questions.question: He is not to blame, nor ……………………… you.
questions.description: When the subjects joined by or or nor are of different persons, the verb agrees in person with the subject nearest to it.

questions.question: You and he ………………………… birds of the same feather.
questions.description: When two singular pronouns are connected by and, the verb is plural.

questions.question: My father and I ………………………. lived here for many years.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected by and, the verb is plural.

questions.question: Neither praise nor censure ………………………. to bother him.
questions.description: Two or more singular subjects connected by neither … nor take a singular verb.
